trans-unit.source: Quickstart tutorial for R language for Machine Learning | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Quickstart tutorial for R language for Machine Learning | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Use this R programming tutorial to get started quickly using the R language with Azure Machine Learning Studio to create a forecasting solution.
trans-unit.target: Use this R programming tutorial to get started quickly using the R language with Azure Machine Learning Studio to create a forecasting solution.

trans-unit.source: Quickstart tutorial for the R programming language for Azure Machine Learning
trans-unit.target: Quickstart tutorial for the R programming language for Azure Machine Learning

trans-unit.source: Stephen F Elston, Ph.D.
trans-unit.target: Stephen F Elston, Ph.D.

trans-unit.source: Introduction
trans-unit.target: Introduction

trans-unit.source: This quickstart tutorial helps you quickly start extending Azure Machine Learning by using the R programming language.
trans-unit.target: This quickstart tutorial helps you quickly start extending Azure Machine Learning by using the R programming language.

trans-unit.source: Follow this R programming tutorial to create, test and execute R code within Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: Follow this R programming tutorial to create, test and execute R code within Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: As you work through tutorial, you will create a complete forecasting solution by using the R language in Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: As you work through tutorial, you will create a complete forecasting solution by using the R language in Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure Machine Learning contains many powerful machine learning and data manipulation modules.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure Machine Learning contains many powerful machine learning and data manipulation modules.

trans-unit.source: The powerful R language has been described as the lingua franca of analytics.
trans-unit.target: The powerful R language has been described as the lingua franca of analytics.

trans-unit.source: Happily, analytics and data manipulation in Azure Machine Learning can be extended by using R. This combination provides the scalability and ease of deployment of Azure Machine Learning with the flexibility and deep analytics of R.
trans-unit.target: Happily, analytics and data manipulation in Azure Machine Learning can be extended by using R. This combination provides the scalability and ease of deployment of Azure Machine Learning with the flexibility and deep analytics of R.

trans-unit.source: Forecasting and the dataset
trans-unit.target: Forecasting and the dataset

trans-unit.source: Forecasting is a widely employed and quite useful analytical method.
trans-unit.target: Forecasting is a widely employed and quite useful analytical method.

trans-unit.source: Common uses range from predicting sales of seasonal items, determining optimal inventory levels, to predicting macroeconomic variables.
trans-unit.target: Common uses range from predicting sales of seasonal items, determining optimal inventory levels, to predicting macroeconomic variables.

trans-unit.source: Forecasting is typically done with time series models.
trans-unit.target: Forecasting is typically done with time series models.

trans-unit.source: Time series data is data in which the values have a time index.
trans-unit.target: Time series data is data in which the values have a time index.

trans-unit.source: The time index can be regular, e.g. every month or every minute, or irregular.
trans-unit.target: The time index can be regular, e.g. every month or every minute, or irregular.

trans-unit.source: A time series model is based on time series data.
trans-unit.target: A time series model is based on time series data.

trans-unit.source: The R programming language contains a flexible framework and extensive analytics for time series data.
trans-unit.target: The R programming language contains a flexible framework and extensive analytics for time series data.

trans-unit.source: In this quickstart guide we will be working with California dairy production and pricing data.
trans-unit.target: In this quickstart guide we will be working with California dairy production and pricing data.

trans-unit.source: This data includes monthly information on the production of several dairy products and the price of milk fat, a benchmark commodity.
trans-unit.target: This data includes monthly information on the production of several dairy products and the price of milk fat, a benchmark commodity.

trans-unit.source: The data used in this article, along with R scripts, can be [downloaded here][download].
trans-unit.target: The data used in this article, along with R scripts, can be [downloaded here][download].

trans-unit.source: This data was originally synthesized from information available from the University of Wisconsin at http://future.aae.wisc.edu/tab/production.html.
trans-unit.target: This data was originally synthesized from information available from the University of Wisconsin at http://future.aae.wisc.edu/tab/production.html.

trans-unit.source: Organization
trans-unit.target: Organization

trans-unit.source: We will progress through several steps as you learn how to create, test and execute analytics and data manipulation R code in the Azure Machine Learning environment.
trans-unit.target: We will progress through several steps as you learn how to create, test and execute analytics and data manipulation R code in the Azure Machine Learning environment.

trans-unit.source: First we will explore the basics of using the R language in the Azure Machine Learning Studio environment.
trans-unit.target: First we will explore the basics of using the R language in the Azure Machine Learning Studio environment.

trans-unit.source: Then we progress to discussing various aspects of I/O for data, R code and graphics in the Azure Machine Learning environment.
trans-unit.target: Then we progress to discussing various aspects of I/O for data, R code and graphics in the Azure Machine Learning environment.

trans-unit.source: We will then construct the first part of our forecasting solution by creating code for data cleaning and transformation.
trans-unit.target: We will then construct the first part of our forecasting solution by creating code for data cleaning and transformation.

trans-unit.source: With our data prepared we will perform an analysis of the correlations between several of the variables in our dataset.
trans-unit.target: With our data prepared we will perform an analysis of the correlations between several of the variables in our dataset.

trans-unit.source: Finally, we will create a seasonal time series forecasting model for milk production.
trans-unit.target: Finally, we will create a seasonal time series forecasting model for milk production.

trans-unit.source: Interact with R language in Machine Learning Studio
trans-unit.target: Interact with R language in Machine Learning Studio

trans-unit.source: This section takes you through some basics of interacting with the R programming language in the Machine Learning Studio environment.
trans-unit.target: This section takes you through some basics of interacting with the R programming language in the Machine Learning Studio environment.

trans-unit.source: The R language provides a powerful tool to create customized analytics and data manipulation modules within the Azure Machine Learning environment.
trans-unit.target: The R language provides a powerful tool to create customized analytics and data manipulation modules within the Azure Machine Learning environment.

trans-unit.source: I will use RStudio to develop, test and debug R code on a small scale.
trans-unit.target: I will use RStudio to develop, test and debug R code on a small scale.

trans-unit.source: This code is then cut and paste into an [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module in Machine Learning Studio ready to run.
trans-unit.target: This code is then cut and paste into an [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module in Machine Learning Studio ready to run.

trans-unit.source: The Execute R Script module
trans-unit.target: The Execute R Script module

trans-unit.source: Within Machine Learning Studio, R scripts are run within the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.
trans-unit.target: Within Machine Learning Studio, R scripts are run within the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.

trans-unit.source: An example of the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module in Machine Learning Studio is shown in Figure 1.
trans-unit.target: An example of the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module in Machine Learning Studio is shown in Figure 1.

trans-unit.source: R programming language: The Execute R Script module selected in Machine Learning Studio
trans-unit.target: R programming language: The Execute R Script module selected in Machine Learning Studio

trans-unit.source: Figure 1.
trans-unit.target: Figure 1.

trans-unit.source: The Machine Learning Studio environment showing the Execute R Script module selected.
trans-unit.target: The Machine Learning Studio environment showing the Execute R Script module selected.

trans-unit.source: Referring to Figure 1, let's look at some of the key parts of the Machine Learning Studio environment for working with the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.
trans-unit.target: Referring to Figure 1, let's look at some of the key parts of the Machine Learning Studio environment for working with the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.

trans-unit.source: The modules in the experiment are shown in the center pane.
trans-unit.target: The modules in the experiment are shown in the center pane.

trans-unit.source: The upper part of the right pane contains a window to view and edit your R scripts.
trans-unit.target: The upper part of the right pane contains a window to view and edit your R scripts.

trans-unit.source: The lower part of right pane shows some properties of the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script].
trans-unit.target: The lower part of right pane shows some properties of the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script].

trans-unit.source: You can view the error and output logs by clicking on the appropriate spots of this pane.
trans-unit.target: You can view the error and output logs by clicking on the appropriate spots of this pane.

trans-unit.source: We will, of course, be discussing the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] in greater detail in the rest of this document.
trans-unit.target: We will, of course, be discussing the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] in greater detail in the rest of this document.

trans-unit.source: When working with complex R functions, I recommend that you edit, test and debug in RStudio.
trans-unit.target: When working with complex R functions, I recommend that you edit, test and debug in RStudio.

trans-unit.source: As with any software development, extend your code incrementally and test it on small simple test cases.
trans-unit.target: As with any software development, extend your code incrementally and test it on small simple test cases.

trans-unit.source: Then cut and paste your functions into the R script window of the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.
trans-unit.target: Then cut and paste your functions into the R script window of the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.

trans-unit.source: This approach allows you to harness both the RStudio integrated development environment (IDE) and the power of Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: This approach allows you to harness both the RStudio integrated development environment (IDE) and the power of Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: Execute R code
trans-unit.target: Execute R code

trans-unit.source: Any R code in the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module will execute when you run the experiment by clicking on the **Run** button.
trans-unit.target: Any R code in the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module will execute when you run the experiment by clicking on the **Run** button.

trans-unit.source: When execution has completed, a check mark will appear on the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] icon.
trans-unit.target: When execution has completed, a check mark will appear on the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] icon.

trans-unit.source: Defensive R coding for Azure Machine Learning
trans-unit.target: Defensive R coding for Azure Machine Learning

trans-unit.source: If you are developing R code for, say, a web service by using Azure Machine Learning, you should definitely plan how your code will deal with an unexpected data input and exceptions.
trans-unit.target: If you are developing R code for, say, a web service by using Azure Machine Learning, you should definitely plan how your code will deal with an unexpected data input and exceptions.

trans-unit.source: To maintain clarity, I have not included much in the way of checking or exception handling in most of the code examples shown.
trans-unit.target: To maintain clarity, I have not included much in the way of checking or exception handling in most of the code examples shown.

trans-unit.source: However, as we proceed I will give you several examples of functions by using R's exception handling capability.
trans-unit.target: However, as we proceed I will give you several examples of functions by using R's exception handling capability.

trans-unit.source: If you need a more complete treatment of R exception handling, I recommend you read the applicable sections of the book by Wickham listed in [Appendix B - Further Reading](#appendixb).
trans-unit.target: If you need a more complete treatment of R exception handling, I recommend you read the applicable sections of the book by Wickham listed in [Appendix B - Further Reading](#appendixb).

trans-unit.source: Debug and test R in Machine Learning Studio
trans-unit.target: Debug and test R in Machine Learning Studio

trans-unit.source: To reiterate, I recommend you test and debug your R code on a small scale in RStudio.
trans-unit.target: To reiterate, I recommend you test and debug your R code on a small scale in RStudio.

trans-unit.source: However, there are cases where you will need to track down R code problems in the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] itself.
trans-unit.target: However, there are cases where you will need to track down R code problems in the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] itself.

trans-unit.source: In addition, it is good practice to check your results in Machine Learning Studio.
trans-unit.target: In addition, it is good practice to check your results in Machine Learning Studio.

trans-unit.source: Output from the execution of your R code and on the Azure Machine Learning platform is found primarily in output.log.
trans-unit.target: Output from the execution of your R code and on the Azure Machine Learning platform is found primarily in output.log.

trans-unit.source: Some additional information will be seen in error.log.
trans-unit.target: Some additional information will be seen in error.log.

trans-unit.source: If an error occurs in Machine Learning Studio while running your R code, your first course of action should be to look at error.log.
trans-unit.target: If an error occurs in Machine Learning Studio while running your R code, your first course of action should be to look at error.log.

trans-unit.source: This file can contain useful error messages to help you understand and correct your error.
trans-unit.target: This file can contain useful error messages to help you understand and correct your error.

trans-unit.source: To view error.log, click on **View error log** on the **properties pane** for the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] containing the error.
trans-unit.target: To view error.log, click on **View error log** on the **properties pane** for the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] containing the error.

trans-unit.source: For example, I ran the following R code, with an undefined variable y, in an [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module:
trans-unit.target: For example, I ran the following R code, with an undefined variable y, in an [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module:

trans-unit.source: This code fails to execute, resulting in an error condition.
trans-unit.target: This code fails to execute, resulting in an error condition.

trans-unit.source: Clicking on **View error log** on the **properties pane** produces the display shown in Figure 2.
trans-unit.target: Clicking on **View error log** on the **properties pane** produces the display shown in Figure 2.

trans-unit.source: Error message pop up
trans-unit.target: Error message pop up

trans-unit.source: Figure 2.
trans-unit.target: Figure 2.

trans-unit.source: Error message pop-up.
trans-unit.target: Error message pop-up.

trans-unit.source: It looks like we need to look in output.log to see the R error message.
trans-unit.target: It looks like we need to look in output.log to see the R error message.

trans-unit.source: Click on the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] and then click on the **View output.log** item on the **properties pane** to the right.
trans-unit.target: Click on the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] and then click on the **View output.log** item on the **properties pane** to the right.

trans-unit.source: A new browser window opens, and I see the following.
trans-unit.target: A new browser window opens, and I see the following.

trans-unit.source: This error message contains no surprises and clearly identifies the problem.
trans-unit.target: This error message contains no surprises and clearly identifies the problem.

trans-unit.source: To inspect the value of any object in R, you can print these values to the output.log file.
trans-unit.target: To inspect the value of any object in R, you can print these values to the output.log file.

trans-unit.source: The rules for examining object values are essentially the same as in an interactive R session.
trans-unit.target: The rules for examining object values are essentially the same as in an interactive R session.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you type a variable name on a line, the value of the object will be printed to the output.log file.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you type a variable name on a line, the value of the object will be printed to the output.log file.

trans-unit.source: Packages in Machine Learning Studio
trans-unit.target: Packages in Machine Learning Studio

trans-unit.source: Azure Machine Learning comes with over 350 preinstalled R language packages.
trans-unit.target: Azure Machine Learning comes with over 350 preinstalled R language packages.

trans-unit.target: You can use the following code in the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module to retrieve a list of the preinstalled packages.

trans-unit.target: In the rest of this document we will extensively discuss using R in the Azure Machine Learning environment.

trans-unit.source: Introduction to RStudio
trans-unit.target: Introduction to RStudio

trans-unit.source: RStudio is a widely used IDE for R. I will use RStudio for editing, testing and debugging some of the R code used in this quick start guide.
trans-unit.target: RStudio is a widely used IDE for R. I will use RStudio for editing, testing and debugging some of the R code used in this quick start guide.

trans-unit.source: Once R code is tested and ready, you simply cut and paste from the RStudio editor into a Machine Learning Studio [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.
trans-unit.target: Once R code is tested and ready, you simply cut and paste from the RStudio editor into a Machine Learning Studio [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.

trans-unit.source: If you do not have the R programming language installed on your desktop machine, I recommend you do so now.
trans-unit.target: If you do not have the R programming language installed on your desktop machine, I recommend you do so now.

trans-unit.source: Free downloads of open source R language are available at the Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN) at [http://www.r-project.org/](http://www.r-project.org/).
trans-unit.target: Free downloads of open source R language are available at the Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN) at [http://www.r-project.org/](http://www.r-project.org/).

trans-unit.source: There are downloads available for Windows, Mac OS, and Linux/UNIX.
trans-unit.target: There are downloads available for Windows, Mac OS, and Linux/UNIX.

trans-unit.source: Choose a nearby mirror and follow the download directions.
trans-unit.target: Choose a nearby mirror and follow the download directions.

trans-unit.source: In addition, CRAN contains a wealth of useful analytics and data manipulation packages.
trans-unit.target: In addition, CRAN contains a wealth of useful analytics and data manipulation packages.

trans-unit.source: If you are new to RStudio, you should download and install the desktop version.
trans-unit.target: If you are new to RStudio, you should download and install the desktop version.

trans-unit.source: You can find the RStudio downloads for Windows, Mac OS, and Linux/UNIX at http://www.rstudio.com/products/RStudio/.
trans-unit.target: You can find the RStudio downloads for Windows, Mac OS, and Linux/UNIX at http://www.rstudio.com/products/RStudio/.

trans-unit.source: Follow the directions provided to install RStudio on your desktop machine.
trans-unit.target: Follow the directions provided to install RStudio on your desktop machine.

trans-unit.source: A tutorial introduction to RStudio is available at https://support.rstudio.com/hc/sections/200107586-Using-RStudio.
trans-unit.target: A tutorial introduction to RStudio is available at https://support.rstudio.com/hc/sections/200107586-Using-RStudio.

trans-unit.source: I provide some additional information on using RStudio in [Appendix A][appendixa].
trans-unit.target: I provide some additional information on using RStudio in [Appendix A][appendixa].

trans-unit.source: Get data in and out of the Execute R Script module
trans-unit.target: Get data in and out of the Execute R Script module

trans-unit.source: In this section we will discuss how you get data into and out of the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.
trans-unit.target: In this section we will discuss how you get data into and out of the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.

trans-unit.source: We will review how to handle various data types read into and out of the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.
trans-unit.target: We will review how to handle various data types read into and out of the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.

trans-unit.source: Load and check data in Machine Learning Studio
trans-unit.target: Load and check data in Machine Learning Studio

trans-unit.source: Load the dataset
trans-unit.target: Load the dataset

trans-unit.source: We will start by loading the **csdairydata.csv** file into Azure Machine Learning Studio.
trans-unit.target: We will start by loading the **csdairydata.csv** file into Azure Machine Learning Studio.

trans-unit.source: Start your Azure Machine Learning Studio environment.
trans-unit.target: Start your Azure Machine Learning Studio environment.

trans-unit.source: Click on the + at the lower left of your screen and select **Dataset**.
trans-unit.target: Click on the + at the lower left of your screen and select **Dataset**.

trans-unit.source: Select **From Local File**, and then **Browse** to select the file.
trans-unit.target: Select **From Local File**, and then **Browse** to select the file.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you have selected **Generic CSV file with header (.csv)** as the type for the dataset.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you have selected **Generic CSV file with header (.csv)** as the type for the dataset.

trans-unit.source: Click the check mark.
trans-unit.target: Click the check mark.

trans-unit.source: After the dataset has been uploaded, you should see the new dataset by clicking on the **Datasets** tab.
trans-unit.target: After the dataset has been uploaded, you should see the new dataset by clicking on the **Datasets** tab.

trans-unit.source: Create an experiment
trans-unit.target: Create an experiment

trans-unit.source: Now that we have some data in Machine Learning Studio, we need to create an experiment to do the analysis.
trans-unit.target: Now that we have some data in Machine Learning Studio, we need to create an experiment to do the analysis.

trans-unit.source: Click on the + at the lower left and select **Experiment**, then **Blank Experiment**.
trans-unit.target: Click on the + at the lower left and select **Experiment**, then **Blank Experiment**.

trans-unit.source: You can name your experiment by selecting, and modifying, the **Experiment created on ...** title at the top of the page.
trans-unit.target: You can name your experiment by selecting, and modifying, the **Experiment created on ...** title at the top of the page.

trans-unit.source: For example, changing it to **CA Dairy Analysis**.
trans-unit.target: For example, changing it to **CA Dairy Analysis**.

trans-unit.source: On the left of the experiment page, expand **Saved Datasets**, and then **My Datasets**.
trans-unit.target: On the left of the experiment page, expand **Saved Datasets**, and then **My Datasets**.

trans-unit.source: You should see the **cadairydata.csv** that you uploaded earlier.
trans-unit.target: You should see the **cadairydata.csv** that you uploaded earlier.

trans-unit.source: Drag and drop the **csdairydata.csv dataset** onto the experiment.
trans-unit.target: Drag and drop the **csdairydata.csv dataset** onto the experiment.

trans-unit.source: In the **Search experiment items** box on the top of the left pane, type [Execute R Script][execute-r-script].
trans-unit.target: In the **Search experiment items** box on the top of the left pane, type [Execute R Script][execute-r-script].

trans-unit.source: You will see the module appear in the search list.
trans-unit.target: You will see the module appear in the search list.

trans-unit.source: Drag and drop the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module onto your pallet.
trans-unit.target: Drag and drop the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module onto your pallet.

trans-unit.source: Connect the output of the **csdairydata.csv dataset** to the leftmost input (**Dataset1**) of the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script].
trans-unit.target: Connect the output of the **csdairydata.csv dataset** to the leftmost input (**Dataset1**) of the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script].

trans-unit.source: Don't forget to click on 'Save'!
trans-unit.target: Don't forget to click on 'Save'!

trans-unit.source: At this point your experiment should look something like Figure 3.
trans-unit.target: At this point your experiment should look something like Figure 3.

trans-unit.source: First R script
trans-unit.target: First R script

trans-unit.source: Let's create a simple first R script to experiment with in Azure Machine Learning Studio.
trans-unit.target: Let's create a simple first R script to experiment with in Azure Machine Learning Studio.

trans-unit.source: I have created and tested the following script in RStudio.
trans-unit.target: I have created and tested the following script in RStudio.

trans-unit.source: Now I need to transfer this script to Azure Machine Learning Studio.
trans-unit.target: Now I need to transfer this script to Azure Machine Learning Studio.

trans-unit.source: I could simply cut and paste.
trans-unit.target: I could simply cut and paste.

trans-unit.source: However, in this case, I will transfer my R script via a zip file.
trans-unit.target: However, in this case, I will transfer my R script via a zip file.

trans-unit.source: Data input to the Execute R Script module
trans-unit.target: Data input to the Execute R Script module

trans-unit.source: Let's have a look at the inputs to the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.
trans-unit.target: Let's have a look at the inputs to the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.

trans-unit.source: In this example we will read the California dairy data into the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.
trans-unit.target: In this example we will read the California dairy data into the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.

trans-unit.source: There are three possible inputs for the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.
trans-unit.target: There are three possible inputs for the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.

trans-unit.source: You may use any one or all of these inputs, depending on your application.
trans-unit.target: You may use any one or all of these inputs, depending on your application.

trans-unit.source: It is also perfectly reasonable to use an R script that takes no input at all.
trans-unit.target: It is also perfectly reasonable to use an R script that takes no input at all.

trans-unit.source: Let's look at each of these inputs, going from left to right.
trans-unit.target: Let's look at each of these inputs, going from left to right.

trans-unit.source: You can see the names of each of the inputs by placing your cursor over the input and reading the tooltip.
trans-unit.target: You can see the names of each of the inputs by placing your cursor over the input and reading the tooltip.

trans-unit.source: Script Bundle
trans-unit.target: Script Bundle

trans-unit.source: The Script Bundle input allows you to pass the contents of a zip file into [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.
trans-unit.target: The Script Bundle input allows you to pass the contents of a zip file into [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.

trans-unit.source: In this section we will perform some basic data filtering and transformation operations on the California dairy data.
trans-unit.target: In this section we will perform some basic data filtering and transformation operations on the California dairy data.

trans-unit.source: By the end of this section we will have data in a format suitable for building an analytic model.
trans-unit.target: By the end of this section we will have data in a format suitable for building an analytic model.

trans-unit.source: More specifically, in this section we will perform several common data cleaning and transformation tasks: type transformation, filtering on dataframes, adding new computed columns, and value transformations.

trans-unit.source: Type transformations
trans-unit.target: Type transformations

trans-unit.source: Now that we can read the California dairy data into the R code in the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module, we need to ensure that the data in the columns has the intended type and format.
trans-unit.target: Now that we can read the California dairy data into the R code in the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module, we need to ensure that the data in the columns has the intended type and format.

trans-unit.source: R is a dynamically typed language, which means that data types are coerced from one to another as required.
trans-unit.target: R is a dynamically typed language, which means that data types are coerced from one to another as required.

trans-unit.source: The atomic data types in R include numeric, logical and character.
trans-unit.target: The atomic data types in R include numeric, logical and character.

trans-unit.source: The factor type is used to compactly store categorical data.
trans-unit.target: The factor type is used to compactly store categorical data.

trans-unit.source: You can find much more information on data types in the references in [Appendix B - Further reading](#appendixb).
trans-unit.target: You can find much more information on data types in the references in [Appendix B - Further reading](#appendixb).

trans-unit.source: When tabular data is read into R from an external source, it is always a good idea to check the resulting types in the columns.
trans-unit.target: When tabular data is read into R from an external source, it is always a good idea to check the resulting types in the columns.

trans-unit.source: You may want a column of type character, but in many cases this will show up as factor or vice versa.
trans-unit.target: You may want a column of type character, but in many cases this will show up as factor or vice versa.

trans-unit.source: In other cases a column you think should be numeric is represented by character data, e.g. '1.23' rather than 1.23 as a floating point number.
trans-unit.target: In other cases a column you think should be numeric is represented by character data, e.g. '1.23' rather than 1.23 as a floating point number.

trans-unit.source: Fortunately, it is easy to convert one type to another, as long as mapping is possible.
trans-unit.target: Fortunately, it is easy to convert one type to another, as long as mapping is possible.

trans-unit.source: For example, you cannot convert 'Nevada' into a numeric value, but you can convert it to a factor (categorical variable).
trans-unit.target: For example, you cannot convert 'Nevada' into a numeric value, but you can convert it to a factor (categorical variable).

trans-unit.source: As another example, you can convert a numeric 1 into a character '1' or a factor.
trans-unit.target: As another example, you can convert a numeric 1 into a character '1' or a factor.

trans-unit.source: The syntax for any of these conversions is simple: `as.datatype()`.
trans-unit.target: The syntax for any of these conversions is simple: `as.datatype()`.

trans-unit.source: Value transformations
trans-unit.target: Value transformations

trans-unit.source: In this section we will perform some simple transformations on the values in some of the columns of our dataframe.
trans-unit.target: In this section we will perform some simple transformations on the values in some of the columns of our dataframe.

trans-unit.source: The R language supports nearly arbitrary value transformations.
trans-unit.target: The R language supports nearly arbitrary value transformations.

trans-unit.source: The references in [Appendix B - Further Reading](#appendixb) contain extensive examples.
trans-unit.target: The references in [Appendix B - Further Reading](#appendixb) contain extensive examples.

trans-unit.source: If you look at the values in the summaries of our dataframe you should see something odd here.
trans-unit.target: If you look at the values in the summaries of our dataframe you should see something odd here.

trans-unit.source: Is more ice cream than milk produced in California?
trans-unit.target: Is more ice cream than milk produced in California?

trans-unit.source: No, of course not, as this makes no sense, sad as this fact may be to some of us ice cream lovers.
trans-unit.target: No, of course not, as this makes no sense, sad as this fact may be to some of us ice cream lovers.

trans-unit.source: The units are different.
trans-unit.target: The units are different.

trans-unit.source: The price is in units of US pounds, milk is in units of 1 M US pounds, ice cream is in units of 1,000 US gallons, and cottage cheese is in units of 1,000 US pounds.
trans-unit.target: The price is in units of US pounds, milk is in units of 1 M US pounds, ice cream is in units of 1,000 US gallons, and cottage cheese is in units of 1,000 US pounds.

trans-unit.source: Assuming ice cream weighs about 6.5 pounds per gallon, we can easily do the multiplication to convert these values so they are all in equal units of 1,000 pounds.
trans-unit.target: Assuming ice cream weighs about 6.5 pounds per gallon, we can easily do the multiplication to convert these values so they are all in equal units of 1,000 pounds.

trans-unit.source: For our forecasting model we use a multiplicative model for trend and seasonal adjustment of this data.
trans-unit.target: For our forecasting model we use a multiplicative model for trend and seasonal adjustment of this data.

trans-unit.source: A log transformation allows us to use a linear model, simplifying this process.
trans-unit.target: A log transformation allows us to use a linear model, simplifying this process.

trans-unit.source: We can apply the log transformation in the same function where the multiplier is applied.
trans-unit.target: We can apply the log transformation in the same function where the multiplier is applied.

trans-unit.source: In the following code, I define a new function, `log.transform()`, and apply it to the rows containing the numerical values.
trans-unit.target: In the following code, I define a new function, `log.transform()`, and apply it to the rows containing the numerical values.

trans-unit.source: The R `Map()` function is used to apply the `log.transform()` function to the selected columns of the dataframe.
trans-unit.target: The R `Map()` function is used to apply the `log.transform()` function to the selected columns of the dataframe.

trans-unit.source: `Map()` is similar to `apply()` but allows for more than one list of arguments to the function.
trans-unit.target: `Map()` is similar to `apply()` but allows for more than one list of arguments to the function.

trans-unit.source: Note that a list of multipliers supplies the second argument to the `log.transform()` function.
trans-unit.target: Note that a list of multipliers supplies the second argument to the `log.transform()` function.

trans-unit.source: The `na.omit()` function is used as a bit of cleanup to ensure we do not have missing or undefined values in the dataframe.
trans-unit.target: The `na.omit()` function is used as a bit of cleanup to ensure we do not have missing or undefined values in the dataframe.

trans-unit.source: There is quite a bit happening in the `log.transform()` function.
trans-unit.target: There is quite a bit happening in the `log.transform()` function.

trans-unit.source: Most of this code is checking for potential problems with the arguments or dealing with exceptions, which can still arise during the computations.
trans-unit.target: Most of this code is checking for potential problems with the arguments or dealing with exceptions, which can still arise during the computations.

trans-unit.source: Only a few lines of this code actually do the computations.
trans-unit.target: Only a few lines of this code actually do the computations.

trans-unit.source: The goal of the defensive programming is to prevent the failure of a single function that prevents processing from continuing.
trans-unit.target: The goal of the defensive programming is to prevent the failure of a single function that prevents processing from continuing.

trans-unit.source: An abrupt failure of a long-running analysis can be quite frustrating for users.
trans-unit.target: An abrupt failure of a long-running analysis can be quite frustrating for users.

trans-unit.source: To avoid this situation, default return values must be chosen that will limit damage to downstream processing.
trans-unit.target: To avoid this situation, default return values must be chosen that will limit damage to downstream processing.

trans-unit.source: A message is also produced to alert users that something has gone wrong.
trans-unit.target: A message is also produced to alert users that something has gone wrong.

trans-unit.source: If you are not used to defensive programming in R, all this code may seem a bit overwhelming.
trans-unit.target: If you are not used to defensive programming in R, all this code may seem a bit overwhelming.

trans-unit.source: I will walk you through the major steps:
trans-unit.target: I will walk you through the major steps:

trans-unit.source: A vector of four messages is defined.
trans-unit.target: A vector of four messages is defined.

trans-unit.source: These messages are used to communicate information about some of the possible errors and exceptions that can occur with this code.
trans-unit.target: These messages are used to communicate information about some of the possible errors and exceptions that can occur with this code.

trans-unit.source: I return a value of NA for each case.
trans-unit.target: I return a value of NA for each case.

trans-unit.source: There are many other possibilities that might have fewer side effects.
trans-unit.target: There are many other possibilities that might have fewer side effects.

trans-unit.source: I could return a vector of zeroes, or the original input vector, for example.
trans-unit.target: I could return a vector of zeroes, or the original input vector, for example.

trans-unit.source: Checks are run on the arguments to the function.
trans-unit.target: Checks are run on the arguments to the function.

trans-unit.source: In each case, if an error is detected, a default value is returned and a message is produced by the `warming()` function.
trans-unit.target: In each case, if an error is detected, a default value is returned and a message is produced by the `warming()` function.

trans-unit.source: I am using `warning()` rather than `stop()` as the latter will terminate execution, exactly what I am trying to avoid.
trans-unit.target: I am using `warning()` rather than `stop()` as the latter will terminate execution, exactly what I am trying to avoid.

trans-unit.source: The log computations are wrapped in `tryCatch()` so that exceptions will not cause an abrupt halt to processing.

trans-unit.source: Without `tryCatch()` most errors raised by R functions result in a stop signal, which does just that.

trans-unit.source: Time series objects and correlation analysis
trans-unit.target: Time series objects and correlation analysis

trans-unit.source: In this section we will explore a few basic R time series objects and analyze the correlations between some of the variables.
trans-unit.target: In this section we will explore a few basic R time series objects and analyze the correlations between some of the variables.

trans-unit.source: Our goal is to output a dataframe containing the pairwise correlation information at several lags.
trans-unit.target: Our goal is to output a dataframe containing the pairwise correlation information at several lags.

trans-unit.source: The complete R code for this section is in the zip file you downloaded earlier.
trans-unit.target: The complete R code for this section is in the zip file you downloaded earlier.

trans-unit.source: Time series objects in R
trans-unit.target: Time series objects in R

trans-unit.source: As already mentioned, time series are a series of data values indexed by time.
trans-unit.target: As already mentioned, time series are a series of data values indexed by time.

trans-unit.source: R time series objects are used to create and manage the time index.
trans-unit.target: R time series objects are used to create and manage the time index.

trans-unit.source: There are several advantages to using time series objects.
trans-unit.target: There are several advantages to using time series objects.

trans-unit.source: Time series objects free you from the many details of managing the time series index values that are encapsulated in the object.
trans-unit.target: Time series objects free you from the many details of managing the time series index values that are encapsulated in the object.

trans-unit.source: In addition, time series objects allow you to use the many time series methods for plotting, printing, modeling, etc.
trans-unit.target: In addition, time series objects allow you to use the many time series methods for plotting, printing, modeling, etc.

trans-unit.source: The POSIXct time series class is commonly used and is relatively simple.
trans-unit.target: The POSIXct time series class is commonly used and is relatively simple.

trans-unit.source: This time series class measures time from the start of the epoch, January 1, 1970.
trans-unit.target: This time series class measures time from the start of the epoch, January 1, 1970.

trans-unit.source: We will use POSIXct time series objects in this example.
trans-unit.target: We will use POSIXct time series objects in this example.

trans-unit.source: Other widely used R time series object classes include zoo and xts, extensible time series.
trans-unit.target: Other widely used R time series object classes include zoo and xts, extensible time series.

Time series example: seasonal forecasting
Our data is now in a form suitable for analysis, and we have determined there are no significant correlations between the variables.
trans-unit.target:
Time series example: seasonal forecasting
Our data is now in a form suitable for analysis, and we have determined there are no significant correlations between the variables.

trans-unit.source: Let's move on and create a time series forecasting model.
trans-unit.target: Let's move on and create a time series forecasting model.

trans-unit.source: Using this model we will forecast California milk production for the 12 months of 2013.
trans-unit.target: Using this model we will forecast California milk production for the 12 months of 2013.

trans-unit.source: Our forecasting model will have two components, a trend component and a seasonal component.
trans-unit.target: Our forecasting model will have two components, a trend component and a seasonal component.

trans-unit.source: The complete forecast is the product of these two components.
trans-unit.target: The complete forecast is the product of these two components.

trans-unit.source: This type of model is known as a multiplicative model.
trans-unit.target: This type of model is known as a multiplicative model.

trans-unit.source: The alternative is an additive model.
trans-unit.target: The alternative is an additive model.

trans-unit.source: We have already applied a log transformation to the variables of interest, which makes this analysis tractable.
trans-unit.target: We have already applied a log transformation to the variables of interest, which makes this analysis tractable.

trans-unit.source: There are many books on R that can help you get started.
trans-unit.target: There are many books on R that can help you get started.

trans-unit.source:
Here are a few I find useful:
- The Art of R Programming: A Tour of Statistical Software Design by Norman Matloff is an excellent introduction to programming in R.
- R Cookbook by Paul Teetor provides a problem and solution approach to using R.
- R in Action by Robert Kabacoff is another useful introductory book.
trans-unit.target:
Here are a few I find useful:
- The Art of R Programming: A Tour of Statistical Software Design by Norman Matloff is an excellent introduction to programming in R.
- R Cookbook by Paul Teetor provides a problem and solution approach to using R.
- R in Action by Robert Kabacoff is another useful introductory book.

trans-unit.source: The companion Quick R website is a useful resource at http://www.statmethods.net/.
trans-unit.target: The companion Quick R website is a useful resource at http://www.statmethods.net/.

trans-unit.source: - R Inferno by Patrick Burns is a surprisingly humorous book that deals with a number of tricky and difficult topics that can be encountered when programming in R. The book is available for free at http://www.burns-stat.com/documents/books/the-r-inferno/.
trans-unit.target: - R Inferno by Patrick Burns is a surprisingly humorous book that deals with a number of tricky and difficult topics that can be encountered when programming in R. The book is available for free at http://www.burns-stat.com/documents/books/the-r-inferno/.
